'Electrochemiluminescence' or 'electrogenerated chemiluminescence' ('ECL') is
a kind of luminescence produced during electrochemical reactions in solutions.
In electrogenerated chemiluminescence, electrochemically generated
intermediates undergo a highly exergonic reaction to produce an electronically
excited state that then emits light upon relaxation to a lower-level state.
This wavelength of the emitted photon of light corresponds to the energy gap
between these two states. ECL excitation can be
caused by energetic electron transfer (redox) reactions of electrogenerated
species. Such luminescence excitation is a form of chemiluminescence where
one/all reactants are produced electrochemically on the
electrodes. Electrogenerated Chemiluminescence, Edited by Allen J. Bard,
Marcel Dekker, Inc., 2004

ECL is usually observed during application of potential (several volts) to
electrodes of electrochemical cell that contains solution of luminescent species
